pullrequest.title: Add Static Map Plugin for creating textured map model

content.raw: Just curious, would `SpawnModel` also work with the full path? If so, that would be less ambiguous than using `model://`, in the unlikely case there is another model with the same name in the path.
content.html: Just curious, would SpawnModel also work with the full path? If so, that would be less ambiguous than using model://, in the unlikely case there is another model with the same name in the path.

pullrequest.title: Add Static Map Plugin for creating textured map model

content.raw: full path should work but I've been avoiding the use of absolute path due to portability. I added an option `<use_cache>` to spawn the model if it already exists so users could enable that to avoid overwriting existing model.
content.html: full path should work but I've been avoiding the use of absolute path due to portability. I added an option <use_cache> to spawn the model if it already exists so users could enable that to avoid overwriting existing model.

pullrequest.title: Add Static Map Plugin for creating textured map model

content.raw: Ok, sounds good. We could consider adding the map type to the model name too, so a satellite and a terrain version of the same area could coexist. But this could become too verbose, so I'm fine with the way it is.
content.html: Ok, sounds good. We could consider adding the map type to the model name too, so a satellite and a terrain version of the same area could coexist. But this could become too verbose, so I'm fine with the way it is.

pullrequest.title: Add Static Map Plugin for creating textured map model
Add Static Map Plugin for creating textured map model

content.raw:
Works well for me. I also placed some cars on the roads and the scale seems to be about right.

I was trying to load a very high latitude to test limits and ran into a problem/limitation which may be on Google's side. `-54.807864 -68.303979` shows up on google maps, but can't seem to be loaded with the API.
content.html:
Works well for me. I also placed some cars on the roads and the scale seems to be about right.

I was trying to load a very high latitude to test limits and ran into a problem/limitation which may be on Google's side. -54.807864 -68.303979 shows up on google maps, but can't seem to be loaded with the API.

pullrequest.title: Add Static Map Plugin for creating textured map model

content.raw: google probably doesn't have satellite images at that zoom level (21). Testing with `<zoom>20</zoom>` works but just gives very pixelated images.
content.html: google probably doesn't have satellite images at that zoom level (21). Testing with <zoom>20</zoom> works but just gives very pixelated images.

pullrequest.title: Add Static Map Plugin for creating textured map model

content.raw: Thanks! I assumed it would fallback to a lower resolution if the zoom was too close.
content.html: Thanks! I assumed it would fallback to a lower resolution if the zoom was too close.

pullrequest.title: Add Static Map Plugin for creating textured map model

content.raw: The test fails for me locally, and I think this is expected, since the world doesn't have a valid API key, right? Not sure if it will be possible to test the download itself, maybe we'll only be able to test a cached file.
content.html: The test fails for me locally, and I think this is expected, since the world doesn't have a valid API key, right? Not sure if it will be possible to test the download itself, maybe we'll only be able to test a cached file.

pullrequest.title: Add Static Map Plugin for creating textured map model

content.raw: Actually the test should pass. The downloads fail without API key but will still create images that are invalid files. Where does the test fail for you? It's passing on [jenkins](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-ci-pr_any-xenial-amd64-gpu-nvidia/388/)
content.html: Actually the test should pass. The downloads fail without API key but will still create images that are invalid files. Where does the test fail for you? It's passing on jenkins
